semantic_title: Coding Abnormal Findings as Additional Diagnoses

content.full_text: Abnormal findings (laboratory, x-ray, pathologic, and other diagnostic results) are not coded and reported unless the provider indicates their clinical significance. If the findings are outside the normal range and the provider has ordered other tests to evaluate the condition or prescribed treatment, it is appropriate to ask the provider whether the abnormal finding should be added. Please note: This differs from the coding practices in the outpatient setting for coding encounters for diagnostic tests that have been interpreted by a provider. (Evidence: pg no: 111, L79-L81)
content.summary: Abnormal findings should only be coded when the provider indicates clinical significance, differing from outpatient coding practices (Evidence: pg no: 111, L79-L81)
key_concepts: Abnormal findings not coded unless clinically significant (Evidence: pg no: 111, L79)
Provider must indicate clinical significance (Evidence: pg no: 111, L79)

detailed_rules.explanation: Abnormal test results should not be coded unless the provider specifically indicates they are clinically significant to the patient's care (Evidence: pg no: 111, L79)

detailed_rules.explanation: When abnormal findings prompt additional testing or treatment, coders should query the provider about the clinical significance and whether the finding should be coded (Evidence: pg no: 111, L80)

detailed_rules.rule_text: This differs from the coding practices in the outpatient setting for coding encounters for diagnostic tests that have been interpreted by a provider (Evidence: pg no: 111, L80-L81)
detailed_rules.explanation: Inpatient coding of abnormal findings follows different rules than outpatient coding for diagnostic test encounters (Evidence: pg no: 111, L80-L81)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify abnormal findings in documentation
Step 2: Determine if provider indicated clinical significance
Step 3: If significance unclear but tests/treatment ordered, query provider
Step 4: Code only clinically significant abnormal findings

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted for pneumonia with incidental elevated glucose not addressed by provider
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient admitted for pneumonia. Lab shows glucose 180 mg/dL. Provider does not comment on glucose level or order diabetes workup.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify pneumonia as principal diagnosis
Step 3: Determine provider did not indicate clinical significance
Step 4: Do not code elevated glucose

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not code abnormal glucose without provider indication of significance
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Coding all abnormal findings regardless of clinical significance

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with pneumonia and elevated creatinine prompting nephrology consult

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify pneumonia as principal diagnosis
Step 2: Note elevated creatinine with nephrology consult
Step 3: Determine provider actions indicate clinical significance
Step 4: Code acute kidney injury as additional diagnosis
